column2: Guinea-Bissau, a small nation on the coast of West Africa, has made a quantum leap into the future. In May 2024, the country successfully launched a blockchain platform—as part of the country’s program with the IMF, under the Extended Credit Facility (ECF)—designed to revolutionize its public wage bill management. Following four years collaborating with the Fund and technological advisor Ernst & Young, and with financial support from selected partners, Guinea-Bissau is moving ahead with implementing this new technology. This initiative, one of the first of its type for Africa, marks a significant leap toward better governance and transparency in government finances. It underscores the country’s commitment to tackling governance challenges and enhancing public service delivery.
column4:
Fiscal Transparency

Using undelying tokenization and smart contract functionality to enable traceability of wage bill funds, validation of payment conditions for salaries and pensions, and alerts and notifications to relevant stakeholders.
column5: Technology Vendor, Ernst and Young  LLP (EY)
column6: ERC 20 token type, but there is no issuance of a native token for end users
column8: Primarily data protection for public sector government agencies in a fragile state
column10: SDG 16 promoting effective and accountable institutions that develop benefits for everyone and tackles corruption. SDG 17 partnerships for goals, in this case on the use of technology and innovation to enhance institutions.
column11: 1) Reduce wage bill to tax revenue ration ; 2) Reduce the ghost employees or unauthorized employees at the public administration; 3) Reduce the nominal wage bill to GDP ratio; 4) Reduce the payments in cash for salaries and pensions
column12:
Ministry of Finances, Ministry of Public Administration

2000 in the initial pilot and 10000+ in the scaling-up.
column13: The the digital platform is live at the Ministry of Finance and Public Administration, it could potentially track the information for all 26,600 public officials and 8,100 pensioners once the project is scaled-up in the next months.
column14: Funding, capacity of public officials, data integrity, political economy, ownership
column15: Ownership needs to be top down and bottom-up, countries needs electricity and  full access to internet to be able to implement this kind of platform
column16: Potentially any country, as long as some digital infrastructure and data integrity are solid enough to run the platform efficiently
column17: Wage bill to Tax Revenue Ratio has decreased from 84 percent in 2020 to 51 percent in 2024. The use of cash for salaries and pensions payments has decreased by 60 percent. The nominal wage bill to GDP has reduced from 6.5 percent of GDP in 2021 to 4.5 percent of GDP in 2024.
column19: Execution
column20: Blockchain solution is part of the larger fiscal transparency and digital government agenda for Guinea-Bissau under the IMF guidance.

column1: Blockchain Pilot Project for Cash Transfers in Refugee Camps
column2: A pilot project leveraging blockchain to transfer salaries to Syrian refugee women enrolled in UN Women’s cash-for-work programmes in Jordan’s Za’atari and Azraq refugee camps. Payments are accessed via iris scans at WFP-linked supermarkets.
column7: Permissioned access; participation through enrolment in Oasis cash-for-work programme
column12: 467 women directly during pilot (2019–2020); potential to scale to 2,500+ yearly participants in Oasis programmes
column13: 3,246 unique transactions; 100% satisfaction with disbursement in Azraq; 94% in Za’atari; 92% confirmed no cash shortfalls; 89% (Azraq) and 78% (Za’atari) found digital wallet better for financial management
column14: Initial delays in knowing when funds were deposited, temporary lack of available cash at supermarkets, digital literacy gaps among women, COVID-19 lockdown affecting physical operations
column15: Flexibility in disbursement empowers beneficiaries, digital wallets support privacy, safety, and savings; IrisGuard system enhances financial control, blockchain enables continuity during emergencies like pandemics
column16: Project expanded to all four Oasis centers as of June 2020, planned rollout to host communities and potential inter-agency blockchain coordination
column17: Oxford University field reports and focus groups with 101 beneficiaries, weekly disbursement led to increased financial independence, use of digital data for trend analysis and program refinement

column1: Traceability for Sustainable Garment and Footwear (Cotton Blockchain)
column2: This initiative aims to improve transparency and traceability in the industry to address labor rights, environmental impacts, and counterfeiting. Led by UNECE and UN/CEFACT, it focuses on creating global standards, policy recommendations, and capacity-building to foster sustainable practices. The initiative includes "The Sustainability Pledge" for stakeholders to commit to ethical and environmentally responsible actions.
column4:
Supply chain management

The pilots ran on a blockchain-based platform constructed with Ethereum testnets. This allowed for permissioned access, tailored to different value chain actors and managed by the UNECE governance framework. The infrastructure was powered by a hybrid open-source stack integrated with the Ethereum testnet environment.
column20: Pilot project as part of XB project on enhancing transparency and traceabilit in garment and footwear supply chains

column1: Blue Circle Marine Plastic Waste Management Platform
column2: The project provides technical support, funding, and tools to help coastal fishermen and low-income residents collect marine waste. The collected plastic waste is transported to processing plants to be recycled into high-value products, with a portion of the revenue shared with the collectors. IoT and blockchain are used to trace the entire process, from collection and transportation to processing and manufacturing, with this data made available to consumers via QR codes for transparency.
column4:
Supply-chain traceability; Climate & Waste Management

The whole life cycle traceability of ocean plastic, including collection, transportation, storage, sorting, regeneration and product manufacturing process

column8: Based on data protection and performance requirements, a consortium chain implementation scheme is adopted to ensure that data is only shared within the consortium and to improve consensus efficiency

10240 boats, 6300 fishers/residents; 6 000 fishers receive low-interest loans.

280 recycling related enterprises

column2: CCC explores how blockchain technology – in combination with other emerging technologies - can improve transparency, traceability, and accountability in carbon markets, emissions reduction, and climate finance. It facilitates the creation of verifiable carbon credits, supports decentralized climate finance, and ensures the sustainability of projects through blockchain-based solutions. In addition to its Web3 focus, the CCC also facilitates multi-stakeholder collaboration towards the development of the data and digital innovation infrastructure – global and local digital public goods – for multistakeholder climate action empowerment
column6: Carbon Credits (such as tokenized carbon assets) are issued as digital tokens on blockchain, allowing transparent trading and verification of carbon reduction efforts.
column12: Governments, climate finance organizations, NGOs, companies investing in sustainable development, and communities affected by climate change. In particular, vulnerable populations in developing nations stand to benefit from improved climate adaptation funding.
column13: Increased verification and transparency in carbon credit trading, reduction in transaction costs for carbon credits, enhanced access to climate finance for developing countries, the number of carbon credits issued and traded on the platform.
column14: Ensuring blockchain solutions can handle large-scale emissions reductions and carbon trading at a global level, the lack of uniform regulatory frameworks for blockchain and carbon credit markets can hinder adoption, ensuring that different blockchain platforms can work together in a seamless manner, blockchain can be complex and may require significant technical expertise to implement and maintain.
column16: The integration of blockchain in carbon markets could revolutionize global emissions reduction efforts by increasing transparency, reducing fraud, and lowering transaction costs, making it easier to scale up climate financing.
column17:
Reduction in carbon emissions from verified projects.
Increase in the volume of carbon credits traded via blockchain.
Amount of green finance mobilized through blockchain mechanisms.
column18: Global, with particular focus on regions in need of climate finance, such as developing countries in Africa, Asia, and Latin America.
column22:
Private sector partnerships (e.g., IBM, Stellar Foundation).
Public and government-backed climate funds (e.g., contributions from countries and multilateral climate finance organizations).
column24: Governed by the UNFCCC’s Paris Agreement and other international climate protocols.

column2: Crypto for more reliable savings communities among low-income populations

Financial Inclusion and Digital Payments

Smart contract-based savings circle management, decentralized transaction tracking, transparent rotation of pooled funds, on-chain reputation system, and integration with crypto wallets (e.g., Valora) using stablecoins like cUSD for predictable value.

column14: Technical integration delays, smart contract and front-end development complexities, coupon system pilot failure, low digital and financial literacy among target users, perceived risk of crypto-based platforms, limited access to mobile phones and connectivity
column15: Personalized guidance at the onboarding stage is essential for adoption in low-literacy or non-crypto communities; strategic partnerships with merchants or financial actors should follow, not precede, the establishment of a strong and active user community; dependencies on third-party blockchain infrastructure (in this case, the Valora wallet integration) require proactive communication with partners and contingency planning to prevent project delays.
column16: High, through its open-source infrastructure, rapid onboarding model, and expansion from Latin America to East Africa
column17: Once users completed the initial onboarding process, over 80% were able to confidently manage savings cycles independently, supporting the platform's potential for sustained use. Feedback from community leaders reinforced the importance of peer support and hands-on onboarding in overcoming the crypto learning curve. The pilot phase also validated ability to replicate savings group behavior in digital form, with 100% of test users successfully creating and managing their savings circles using the platform’s smart contracts.
column19: Seed stage design and prototyping 2021-2022; pilot deployment in Venezuela 2022; pilot Burundi 2024-2025

column2: The Atrium is an interagency development sandbox designed to enable collaboration across UN agencies interested in experimenting with blockchain technology in a secure environment. The Atrium is comprised of two components; a storefront to share blockchain applications, and the underlying infrastructure to test those applications. It will enable members to share and easily launch blockchain applications, to vote on decisions as a community, and to receive badges that will unlock varying permissions within the platform.

column2: To commemorate its 75th anniversary, UNICEF launched the "Patchwork Kingdoms" NFT collection, comprising 1,000 data-driven artworks. column1: Development of the SMS based wallet by Xcapit
column2: SMS based wallet with modern account abstraction backend to enable high programmability and reach to beneficiaries with feature phones. Xcapit is a self-custodial, open-source Web3 wallet designed to enhance financial inclusion in Latin America. It offers wealth management tools, financial planning, low- and middle-risk investment options, and gamified financial education. Users can also make transparent cryptocurrency donations to various causes. Within its first two months, Xcapit onboarded over 14,000 users, primarily from Mexico and Argentina.

column2: Amply is a blockchain-based digital identity protocol designed to replace paper-based attendance records in South African Early Childhood Development (ECD) centers. By providing each child with a self-sovereign digital identity, the system enables accurate tracking of attendance, which can be tokenized and used to claim government subsidies, enhancing transparency and efficiency in funding processes.

column1: Rahat - A blockchain-based platform for aid distribution and anticipatory action
column2:
Extending the Rahat platform to be capable of transferring cryptocurrencies in humanitarian/social protection cash transfers. Rahat is a blockchain-based digital cash and voucher assistance (CVA) management system developed by Rumsan. It aims to enhance transparency, accountability, and efficiency in the distribution of humanitarian aid, particularly in hard-to-reach areas. The system allows for mobile-based blockchain tokens to manage and monitor aid transactions during emergency response and recovery programs.

Rahat is an open-source, blockchain-based platform that enables humanitarian agencies to distribute and manage digital relief through tokens. It supports vulnerable communities by delivering timely, anticipatory cash and voucher assistance, helping them build resilience against climate shocks.

Rahat is a graduate of the UNICEF Venture Fund’s seed stage program, where it improved its main CVA platform and successfully ran a pilot in Jaleswar. It is now part of the fund’s growth stage cohort, working on moving from private digital tokens to crypto-based aid and scaling its humanitarian and anticipatory action system to reach more people.
column4:
Financial inclusion and digital payments

Multi modal digital asset treasury options, integrations with Offramps, Integrations with Anticipatory action modules (in the future), beneficiary management, reporting

- Anticipatory Action Smart Contracts: Automated smart contract triggers are used to initiate aid distribution and early warning messages based on predefined early warning indicators (e.g., weather data, risk thresholds).
- Secure Multisig Wallets: Implements Gnosis SAFE multisig wallets to manage fund approvals, adding an extra layer of security and requiring multiple signatories for any transaction.
- Transparent Cash Distribution: Aid disbursements are recorded on-chain and can be tracked through a block explorer, ensuring transparency and accountability.
- Stable Digital Currency: Utilizes stablecoins (e.g., USDC) to maintain the value of aid and minimize volatility during distribution.
column7: Public & Private blockchain Open to vulnerable communities in Nepal, particularly in flood-prone areas

column15:
- Blockchain Enhances CVA: Blockchain shows strong potential to improve transparency, reduce fraud, and accelerate aid delivery in Cash and Voucher Assistance (CVA) programs.
- Context Matters: Solutions must be adapted to local infrastructure, regulations, and beneficiary needs to be effective.
- User-Centric Design: Interfaces should be simple and accessible for both beneficiaries and administrators to ensure adoption.
- Collaborative Approach: Strong partnerships between humanitarian agencies, local organizations, and tech providers are vital for success.
- Data Protection is Crucial: Privacy and security of beneficiary data must be prioritized in all implementations.
- Scaling is Complex: Expansion of blockchain-based CVA requires strategic planning, resources, and infrastructure readiness.
- Guidance for the Future: Clear procedures, strong M&E frameworks, and local capacity building are essential for future implementations.
For more details - https://www.unicef.org/nepal/media/21181/file/Evaluation%20of%20Rahat%20-%20Summary.pdf

column1: Building Blocks - Beneficiary-centric, blockchain-based network for inter-agency coordination of humanitarian assistance
column2: Building Blocks (BB) is a blockchain network optimized for humanitarian and development use cases. BB is designed for inter-organizational collaboration, coordination and preventative de-duplication to optimize and harmonize assistance by providing a 360° view of which agency is reaching which recipients and with what assistance, ensuring collective assistance is coordinated and equitable, and access to support is also simplified and more convenient.
column4:
Financial inclusion and digital payments

On top of the BB blockchain network, various applications or ‘smart contracts’ of interest to the humanitarian community can be built, made available for free to all network members. Network member WFP has developed a robust and powerful financial value transfer application that facilitates the transfer of value which can be saved, traded and/or consumed, such as food, cash, WASH, medicine and more. New applications optimized for other use cases, for example the transfer of value through information such as Digital ID and Supply Chain, could also be deployed by network members.
column7:
Private, permissioned EVM; participation through engagement as a BB network member under a governance framework.

Alternative route in some operations, BB is made available as a free-of-charge service to the humanitarian community through participation in Cash Working Group (CWG), Food Security & Livelihoods (FSL) and other clusters.
column8: For transaction throughput, cost, and privacy reasons, BB runs on a private-permissioned blockchain, enabling an increase in transaction throughput beyond current and anticipated near future needs, on-chain transaction cost of zero, block (confirmation) time of 5 seconds, and the information on BB to only be visible to its approved humanitarian members.
column9:
No, BB is currently not open source though built on many open-source components.

All smart contracts on BB are available for free to other full BB network members.

Assisting 1 million Syrian and Rohingya refugees in Jordan and Bangladesh through online transfer management since 2017 and 2020.

column1: Etherisc – Blockchain-Based Insurance for Smallholder Farmers
column2: Etherisc is a blockchain-based technology platform which allows end-to-end automation of parametric insurance products. The platform produces a single source of real-time claims data while removing the need for each stakeholder to separately verify weather data before claims are paid out. This automation enables claims to be paid faster while cutting costs. Leveraging blockchain's real-time transaction tracking also enhances transparent monitoring for all stakeholders

Trust among different parties involved in an insurance product
column12:
Smallholder farmers, particularly in developing countries who face financial risk from crop failures due to climate change.
